DetailContent.body: Tachycardia in theatre is often due to inadequate depth of anaesthesia / analgesia or alternatively a reflex to hypotension. Tachycardia should not be treated as an isolated variable: remember to tailor treatment to the patient and the situation. Follow the full steps to exclude a serious underlying problem.

DetailContent.head: Immediate action
DetailContent.body:
Stop any stimulus, Check pulse, rhythm and blood pressure:

  • If no pulse or impending arrest: use Box A.
  • If narrow complex AND not hypotensive first increase depth of anaesthesia/analgesia.

DetailContent.head: Box A: CRITICAL TACHYCARDIA
DetailContent.body:
If no pulse, delegate one person (minimum) to chest compressions →2-1 (Cardiac arrest)

If hypotension worsening or impending arrest, consider electrical cardioversion (Box D)

DetailContent.head: Adequate oxygen delivery
DetailContent.body:
• Check fresh gas flow for circuit in use AND check measured FiO₂.
  • Visual inspection of entire breathing system including valves and connections.
  • Rapidly confirm reservoir bag moving OR ventilator bellows moving.

DetailContent.head: Breathing
DetailContent.body:
• Check chest symmetry, rate, breath sounds, SpO₂, measured VTexp, ETCO₂.
  • Feel the airway pressure using reservoir bag and APL valve <3 breaths.

DetailContent.head: Circulation
DetailContent.body: Check rate, rhythm, perfusion, recheck blood pressure, obtain 12-lead ECG if possible.

DetailContent.head: Box B: POTENTIAL UNDERLYING PROBLEMS
DetailContent.body:
• Stimulation with inadequate depth
  • Consider drug error
  • Also consider: central line/wire; hypovolaemia; primary cardiac arrhythmia; myocardial infarction; electrolyte disturbance; local anaesthetic toxicity →3-10; sepsis →3-14; circulatory embolus, gas/fat/amniotic →3-5; anaphylaxis →3-1; malignant hyperthermia crisis →3-8

DetailContent.head: Box C: DRUGS FOR TACHYCARDIA
DetailContent.body:
• Fluid bolus 10 ml.kg⁻¹ (adult 250 ml)
  • Magnesium 50 mg.kg⁻¹ (adult 2 g) over >10 min, max conc. 200 mg.ml⁻¹
  • Amiodarone 5 mg.kg⁻¹ (adult 300 mg) over >3 min, NOT in polymorphic VT
  • Labetalol 0.5 mg.kg⁻¹ (adult 25-50 mg), repeat when necessary
  • Esmolol 0.5 mg.kg⁻¹ (adult 25-50 mg)
  • Adenosine 0.1 to 0.5 mg.kg⁻¹ (Adult 3 to 18 mg) – for SVT

DetailContent.head: Call for help
DetailContent.body: Consider electrical cardioversion (Box D) if problem not resolving quickly.

DetailContent.head: Box D: ELECTRICAL CARDIOVERSION
DetailContent.body:
• Attach pads and ECG from defibrillator
  • Ensure adequate depth / sedation / analgesia for cardioversion
  • Engage synchronisation and check for sync spikes on R-waves
  • Start with 1 Jkg⁻¹ (adult 50-100 J) biphasic
  • Remember to hold shock button until sync shock delivered

DetailContent.head: Depth
DetailContent.body: Consider current depth of anaesthesia AND adequacy of analgesia.

DetailContent.head: The guidelines in this handbook are not intended to be standards of medical care. The ultimate judgement with regard to a particular clinical procedure or treatment plan must be made by the clinician in the light of the clinical data presented and the diagnostic and treatment options available.
